  • Element
com.sun.faces.annotation

Annotation Type Event


  • @Retention(value=SOURCE)
@Target(value={FIELD,METHOD})
public @interface Event
    Annotation that identifies a component event. An event is a logical entity that consists typically of:
    • an event class or interface
    • an event listener class or interface, with methods that are invoked when an event occurs, and passed an instance of the event class or interface
    • a component "add" method for adding event listeners
    • a component "remove" method for removing event listeners
    • optionally, a component "get" method for obtaining an array of all registered event listeners.
    An event annotation is placed on either of the required listener add or remove methods. It is preferable to annotate the "add" method.

    The annotation for a given event should occur only once per component. An event is uniquely identified by its name().

    An event may be annotated in a component class, a non-component class, or an interface. It is generally a good idea to define common events once, in an abstract base class or interface. Inherited event metadata may be overridden, by providing an annotation on the overriding add or remove method. Annotation element values from the super class will be inherited unless overridden by annotation element values in the child class.

    If names for the listener add and remove methods are not supplied, they may be generated following the standard naming conventions. For example, for an event "blam", if the annotated method has a single parameter, and the method name begins with the prefix "add", and the remaining portion of the name equals the unqualified class name of the singleton parameter, then this method is assumed to be an "add" method for an event listener, and the singleton parameter type is assumed to be the event listener class. The same logic is used to imply the name of the "remove" method.

    The name of an event may also be defaulted, if, in addition to the naming conventions for listener add and remove methods, the event listener class name ends with the suffix "Listener". Hence for an event listener class named BlamListener, the default event name would be "blam".

    If all standard naming conventions are followed, a minimal event annotation for the "blam" event would look like: 

        @Event
    public void addBlamListener(BlamListener blamListener) {...}
    public void removeBlamListener(BlamListener blamListener) {...}

    If the event is to be mapped to a property on the component, then the listener class must define extactly one handler method, e.g.: 

        public interface BlamListener {
        public void blamHappened(BlamEvent blamEvent);
    }

    Note that since add and remove listener methods have the same signature, if default naming conventions are not followed, it is necessary to provide both method names explicitly, e.g. 

        @Event(
        name="blam",
        addListenerMethodName="insertBlamListener",
        removeListenerMethodName="deleteBlamListener"
    )
    public void insertBlamListener(KerBlamListener blamListener) {...}
    public void deleteBlamListener(KerBlamListener blamListener) {...}

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element and Description
      java.lang.String addListenerMethodName
      The name of the "add" method for this event.
      java.lang.String displayName
      The display name, typically used at design-time.
      java.lang.String getListenersMethodName
      The name of the "get" method for this event.
      boolean isDefault
      Indicates whether this event is the default event for its component.
      java.lang.String name
      This event's unique name.
      java.lang.String removeListenerMethodName
      The name of the "remove" method for this event.
      java.lang.String shortDescription
      An optional short description of this event, typically used as a tool tip at design-time.

    • Element Detail

      • name

        public abstract java.lang.String name
        This event's unique name. The name must be unique within the scope of the event's class.
        Default:
        ""

      • displayName

        @Localizable
public abstract java.lang.String displayName
        The display name, typically used at design-time. If no value is provided, the name() will be used.
        Default:
        ""

      • shortDescription

        @Localizable
public abstract java.lang.String shortDescription
        An optional short description of this event, typically used as a tool tip at design-time.
        Default:
        ""

      • addListenerMethodName

        public abstract java.lang.String addListenerMethodName
        The name of the "add" method for this event. A value need be specified only if the annotation is placed elsewhere than the "add" method.
        Default:
        ""

      • removeListenerMethodName

        public abstract java.lang.String removeListenerMethodName
        The name of the "remove" method for this event. A value need be specified only if the annotation is placed elsewhere than the "remove" method, or if the name of the method does not follow standard naming conventions.
        Default:
        ""

      • getListenersMethodName

        public abstract java.lang.String getListenersMethodName
        The name of the "get" method for this event. A value need be specified only if the annotation is placed elsewhere than the "remove" method, or if the name of the method does not follow standard naming conventions.
        Default:
        ""

      • isDefault

        public abstract boolean isDefault
        Indicates whether this event is the default event for its component. Only one event may be declared to be the default event for a component. If a component does not declare a default event and does not inherit a default event, and implements javax.faces.component.ActionSource, the action event will be made the default, if it exists; if it implements javax.faces.component.EditableValueHolder, the valueChange event will be made the default, if it exists.
        Default:
        false
